items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. We expect river levels to remain high until 09:00 on 31/12/21. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. We continue to monitor the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses.

River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses

River levels remain high but are slowly falling at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road. River levels are slowly falling, but still pose a flood risk. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated this evening, Thursday, 30/12/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Saxons Lode river gauge as a result of recent rainfall. Consequently flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 30/12/2021. Flooding may affect low lying land and Roads adjacent the River from Highley to Tewkesbury. Other locations that may be affected include Stourport, Holt Fleet, Worcester, Kempsey, Severn Stoke, Upton upon Severn, South Quay, Diglis Parade and the Hylton Road towpath. Flooded drains may affect the racecourse and Worcester County cricket ground. New Street Gate is currently still closed at Upton upon Severn due to flooding and may be impassable. Saxons Lode has peaked and is falling. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 9am on 31/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Llanymynech river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall overnight. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected between 09:00 and 12:00 today, 30/12/21. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Predicted peak based on forecast rainfall :- Llanymynech 3.2m to 3.7m this afternoon 30/12/21 Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 09:00 on 31/12/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen and remain high at the Lugwardine river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall over the past few days. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue for the next couple of days. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop. Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days and we expect river levels to remain high. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 09:00 on 31/12/21, or if the situation changes

floodArea.riverOrSea: Sandyford Brook, Ridings Brook, Saredon Brook

items.message:
River levels are high but steady at the Milford river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Sow between Great Bridgeford and Shugborough, the River Penk between Coven and Stafford, the Sandyford Brook, the Rising Brook, the Ridings Brook and the Saredon Brook.   We do not forecast the situation to deteriorate any further.
We expect river levels to remain high.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message: River levels remain high at the Sherborne Lake river gauge but are falling. Standing water on low lying land and roads may remain. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded, and refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, Friday 31/12/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Willington Cableway and Shardlow river gauges as a result of persistent rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  
Areas most at risk are farmland in the Willington, Ingleby, Barrow on Trent and Swarkestone and Bargate Lane and the access to Willington Meadows at Willington and Twyford Village access road - Church Lane at Barrow and Ingleby Lane may be affected above this level.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.  
This message will be updated this evening, 30/12/21, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Shropshire, Staffordshire, Telford and Wrekin, Wrexham

items.message: River levels have risen and remain high at the Tern - Walcot river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall over the past few days. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue for the next couple of days. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington. As further rainfall is expected river levels will remain high for the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow morning 31/12/2021 by 09:00, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  

River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. No further flooding to roads and fields is expected, however standing water and debris may remain.  Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours and, therefore, we'll continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

items.description: Upper River Great Ouse in Northamptonshire, Oxfordshire and Buckinghamshire

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Milton Keynes, Oxfordshire, West Northamptonshire

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat from flooding, however standing water and debris may remain.  Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours and therefore we'll continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

The risk of flooding from the River Roding has now reduced and levels have fallen below that of concern. 
There may still be some flooding to fields adjacent to the river and standing water could be seen for several days. However, river levels are forecast to continue to drop over the coming days and these areas of water will clear away.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and reissue this flood alert if the situation changes.

items.description: River Ray and its tributaries from Shipton Lee to and including Islip

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ray, Wootten Brook, Doddershall Brook, Tetchwick Brook, Lugershall Brook, Murswell Hill Brook, Cutters Brook, Piddington Brook, Blackthorn Brook, Panshill Brook, Studley Wood Brook, Beckley Brook, Oddington Brook, Gallos Brook, Chipping Farm Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high but gradually falling on the lower River Ray following recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low-lying land, footpaths and roads is expected to continue today (30/12/21), especially in areas between Lower Arncott and Islip. 
Further rain is forecast this morning, 30/12/21, which should clear by this afternoon. Patchy showers move through the area overnight with the potential to be heavy at times. River levels are steadily falling at Lower Arncott. Levels have now stabilised at Islip but remain very high due to high levels on the River Cherwell. Levels will continue to fall but will remain high and sensitive to further rainfall over the coming days.
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, many of which will be flooded. 
This message will be updated this evening, 30/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: Following further rainfall in the East Devon area in the early hours of Wednesday morning, river levels remain high on the Rivers Clyst, Culm and their tributaries. Further rainfall is forecast throughout the day on Wednesday 29/12/2021, this will maintain the high river levels. Flooding of low lying land and roads close to the river is possible throughout today, Wednesday. No flooding to properties is currently forecast. Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are constantly monitoring river levels and will update this message on Thursday morning, or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Otter and Sid, and Exmouth area
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: The risk of flooding has now reduced, and rivers have fallen below levels of concern. River levels will remain high and will be sensitive to further rainfall. The heavy rainfall experienced in the early hours of Wednesday, 29th December has cleared the area and no further heavy rainfall is forecast. The Environment Agency will continue to monitor the situation and issue any further updates as necessary.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Tamar, River Strat, River Neet, River Ottery, River Kensey

items.message:
This Flood Alert remains in force. Flooding is possible this afternoon and overnight into Thursday 30th December. Last night’s rain has caused river levels to rise and we expect these to remain high throughout the rest of today and into tomorrow morning. 
This may result in flooding to low lying land and roads close to rivers this afternoon and overnight into Thursday morning 30th December. However, flooding to properties is not currently expected. 
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.  We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated on Thursday morning or earlier if the situation changes.

items.message:
Following overnight rain, river levels are steadily rising again on the Rivers Exe, Haddeo, Batherm and Lowman.

Flooding of low lying land and roads close to the river is possible during today, Wednesday 29/12/2021. No flooding to properties is currently forecast. Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.

We are constantly monitoring river levels and will update this message on Thursday, 30/12/2021, or earlier if the situation changes.

items.message: Flooding is possible on Wednesday 29/12/2021. There has been heavy rainfall in the early hours of Wednesday morning on the rivers in the Mid Devon Area. This has caused the rivers to rise and we expect the river levels to remain high throughout Wednesday. Levels suggest that there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river. Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages in this location. River levels will begin to fall again on Thursday. This message will be updated on Thursday morning or earlier if the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Barle, River Exe, River Lyn, River Mole, River Bray

items.message: Flooding is possible on Wednesday, 29/12/2021. Over the last 48 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the Exmoor Rivers area. This means that the Rivers Barle, Lyn, Mole, Bray and upper River Exe are high. Levels suggest that there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river. No flooding to properties is currently forecast. We expect rivers to remain high throughout the day on Wednesday and Thursday. Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Thursday morning or earlier if the situation changes.

This has caused the River Exe to rise and we expect the river levels to remain high throughout Wednesday. Levels suggest that there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river. Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages in this location. River levels will begin to fall again on Thursday. items.description: Middle River Great Ouse in Milton Keynes, Bedford Borough and Central Bedfordshire
items.message:
River levels are falling at the Newport Pagnell Cemetery river gauge but remain high at the Bedford Gauge as a result of recent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is still possible. We expect flooding to affect River Great Ouse from Newport Pagnell to Roxton.   
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high for a few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning 31/12/21, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high on the River Thame downstream of Aylesbury following recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low-lying land, footpaths and roads is expected to continue today, 30/12/21, especially in areas between Thame and Dorchester. 
Further rain is forecast this morning, 30/12/21, which should clear by this afternoon. Patchy showers move through the area overnight with the potential to be heavy at times.  River levels have fallen below the flood risk threshold in the Aylesbury area, but remain high downstream. River levels are high in the Thame area but are gradually falling. Levels continue to rise between Stadhampton and Dorchester. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff will be in the area clearing trash screens. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and avoid contact with flood water. 
This message will be updated this evening, 30/12/21, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are falling on the River Wey following recent rainfall. Rainfall this morning should clear in the afternoon, further showers are forecast overnight into tomorrow, 31/12/21.  We are closely monitoring the situation. Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and remain safe and aware of your local surroundings. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 30/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high on the Lower Cherwell following recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low-lying land, footpaths and roads is expected to continue, especially in Thrupp and Kidlington areas. 
Further rain is forecast this morning, 30/12/21, which should clear by this afternoon. Patchy showers move through the area overnight with the potential to be heavy at times. Levels remain high but are gradually falling in the Thrupp and Kidlington areas. River levels continue to fall in the Lower Heyford area where they should now be mostly back within banks. River levels remain sensitive to further rainfall and will remain high over the coming days.
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, many of which will be flooded. 
This message will be updated this evening, 30/12/21, or as the situation changes.

The risk of flooding from the River Ise and Alledge Brook has now reduced and levels have fallen below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

River levels in the Eastern Yar remain high and rising in places. Today has seen 11mm of rain recorded at Knighton, with 26mm of rain in the last three days. At Alverstone, the river will peak around midnight tonight (Wednesday 29/12/2021). River levels will be near to the top of the bank at Alverstone and impacting cycle tracks and paths at Langbridge. At Sandown, the river will start to rise and peak tomorrow morning (Thursday 30/12/2021), with ongoing flooding to Golf Links Road and Moreton Common Road. Ditches near Fort Holiday Park will struggle to drain. Only light rain is expected over the next few days and the situation will slowly improve, although heavier showers are possible over the weekend which could see rivers rise again. We are operating the sluice at Bembridge to reduce levels at Brading Marshes. We continue to monitor the forecast and keep the river free of any reported blockages. This Flood Alert will be updated or removed by 16:00 on 30/12/2021.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message:
River levels have risen at the Sutton Gault river gauge as a result of rainfall earlier this week. We expect flooding to affect The Causeway at Sutton Gault   
This information is correct as of 07:00 on Thursday 30th December. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 18 centimetres of water currently on the road. Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places.
There are currently no issues on the Earith or Welney Causeways. 
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to continue rising into tomorrow.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with Cambridgeshire Highways, who will decide whether to close the road.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated this afternoon, 30/12/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising at the Sutton Gault river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall.  
This information is correct as of 07:00 on Thursday 30th December. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 18 centimetres of water currently on the road. Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places.
This alert applies to SUTTON GAULT CAUSEWAY ONLY.
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to continue rising into tomorrow.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with Cambridgeshire Highways, who will decide whether to close the road.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated this afternoon, 30/12/21, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message:
River levels remain high but stable at the Bradford on Avon river gauge as a result of recent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from today, 30/12/2021 and into tomorrow 31/12/2021.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed.   
Further patchy but generally light rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high but relatively stable for at least the next 48 hours.
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens and checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures.  
This message will be updated by 20:00 on Thursday, 30/12/2021, or as the situation changes.
